Some would suggest creating "Mock" objects defined within your test that 
pretend to be those external resources.  Sometimes this is a viable 
option, but at some point a directory full of a bunch of xml catalog 
file variations becomes more readable and understandable than a bunch of 
code.  You want to find a medium that works for your situation, rather 
than trying too hard to make your situation fit a set of rules.

T.

On Wednesday, May 1, 2002, at 05:30 PM, David V. Olivier wrote:

> The rule of thumb is that unit tests should be as standalone as 
> possible,
> and dependencies on external resources such as databases or files 
> should be
> minimized or eliminated.  This makes perfect sense.  Tests which rely on
> external resources are  not self-contained, are harder to read, and can 
> be
> broken even if the code is functioning correctly.  However, code does 
> touch
> external resources at some point.  Shouldn't this be tested, and how?
>
> Specifically, I have code that parses a xml catalog file and builds a
> catalog object structure.  I want to verify that the parsing works
> correctly.  In particular, I want to make sure that it robustly handles
> unusual conditions such as catalogs with certain branches missing.  It
> seems to me that the simplest way to do this is to have a test which 
> uses
> the parsing code to parse a very simple catalog and verifies that it 
> builds
> what I expect it to.
>
> But to do this test I do need some external resource, a simple catalog
> file.  Ok.  Now I can't simply look at the test to see what it does.  I
> also have to look at the file.  Are there cleaner alternatives?  Must I
> simply accept that there will occasionally be external resources 
> required
> to test functionality at the boundaries of the system?  If so, are there
> best practices for this scenario?  Am I missing something?  I'd love to
> hear peoples thoughts.
>
